content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

i just did your clash, nice one ! but miss a point about the hexadecimal format => upper case or down case ?
get lucky because the last validator has a b ( and not B ) !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great puzzle with a laconic yet clear statement, would be really fun in the fastest mode!
Maybe you can add to statement that input string only consist of alphabet and digits there is no space or special character.
This prompt is unclear. Hole needs to be explicitly defined as referring to the shape of a character. An example which includes 0,1,and 2 hole characters in the description would be beneficial.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment:

Interessant problem. I have nothing to note to the problem presentation, but your python solution can be improve.
1) You should (you had to!) avoid to named a variable "str". str is a native function of the Python langage and by this way your erase it by redefinition. in this case it works because you don't need of the original function str, but anyway, that is not good thing to show.
So, rename it. "s", or "st", or "word", or "line". I will validate after that ;)
2) You deal with 26+26+10=62 characters. Your list holeTable, have a len of 123 ... Hopefully ord('z') is not so big... It leads also that your code will run for other special character (as #,$,%,&) but return 0 hole for all of these. It will be better if the function return an error in case of non correct input rather than a result, but a wrong or unexpected result. So the solution could be have a dictionary (that contains only the 56 accepted characters), rather than a list.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I tried fastest mode, it is ideal. Shortest mode might be pretty challenging.
The problem is in principle simple, but requires some advanced insight in selected language of choice. Good job.
Hi, default codes for Pascal and VB.Net are not working. It is due to `STRING` is registered keyword and should not be used as identifier (those languages ignore letter case)
Why you assume "0, 4, Q, g" have one hole only?

Maybe the hole table can be in the statement. I don't think it would make the assignment much easier (except for the part when you have to think about all alphanumerical characters in given font family)

It's a good problem, but you'll probably want to be a little more explicit about which characters contain how many holes. See here for a few potential issues: https://i.imgur.com/1fJ5vL8.png

It's not at all strange to think of zero and lowercase G as having two holes. Also, this is pretty much completely inscrutable in reverse mode.

Thanks for the feedback!
Edits:
- Add in Statement: "We assume 0, 4, Q, g have one hole only."
- Remove reverse game mode

Thanks for the feedback!
Edits:
- Add in Statement: The hole table.
To prevent confusion.

Thank you!!!
Edit: Stub generator input
- read STRING:string(1000)
+ read s:string(1000)

Thanks!
Edits:
1.
Change [[str]] to [[s]]
2.
+ Solution throws ValueError.

Good point!
Edit: Statement
+ "Holes" are referring to the shape of characters.
Thanks a lot! I will fix the description.

In your Python solution, variables with name "str" remains.

"str = input()
strHole = holeCount(str)
strHoleHex = hex(holeCount(str))[2:]"

Then, the statement "c.isalpha() or c.isnumeric()" could be replaced by a method already made for that : "c.isalnum()"
